questions.question: Question 1: The most common cause of peripheral vascular disease is?
questions.explanation:
Atherosclerosis is the most common cause of peripheral occlusive vascular disease (POVD). Other 
causes are trauma and emboli. Peripheral arterial insufficiency is predominantly a disease of the lower extremities with the 
superficial femoral and iliac arteries commonly affected.

questions.question: Question 2: What is the most common symptom of peripheral occlusive vascular disease?
questions.explanation:
The most common symptom of peripheral obstructive vascular disease is intermittent 
claudication. Intermittent claudication is the debilitating cramp-like pain felt in the leg muscles due to reduced 
blood flow brought on by peripheral arterial disease. It usually signifies mild to moderate chronic 
vascular occlusive disease. Rest pain is when the disease progresses to a degree that perfusion is severely reduced and 
cramp-like pain in the calf is felt even at rest. A swollen and erythematous limb is seen in critical limb ischemia. When the limb is in the 
dependent position, there is pooling of blood which causes the limb to appear red and 
swollen(sunset foot sign). Buerger's test is done to assess the severity of peripheral vascular disease. In normal individuals, 
the elevation of the lower limb to a 90-degree angle does not produce any pallor but in affected 
individuals, even at an elevation of 20-degrees, pallor and venous guttering of the limb can be 
seen.

questions.question:
Question 3: A 60-year-old man presented to the OPD with complaints of pain in the lower limbs, on 
walking a certain distance. He noticed that the pain subsides on resting. Which of the 
following is false regarding this condition?

options.a: Pain is usually felt in the calf muscles
options.b: Muscle group affected is below the level of arterial disease
options.c: Distance at which pain occurs varies greatly from day to day
options.d: Worsened by anemia or heart failure

questions.explanation:
The patient is likely experiencing intermittent claudication due to peripheral occlusive vascular 
disease. 1171 
Sold by @itachibot Intermittent claudication is the debilitating cramp-like pain felt in the leg muscles due to reduced 
blood flow brought on by peripheral arterial disease. It usually signifies mild to moderate chronic 
vascular occlusive disease. The pain classically occurs during activity and is relieved with rest. The distance that a patient can 
walk without stopping till the pain is experienced in the muscles is known as claudication 
distance. This distance varies only slightly from day-to-day. The muscle group affected is one 
anatomical level below the arterial disease. Boydâ€™s classification Class l - Pain on walking but pain decreases on continuation of walking. Class ll - Pain on walking, but continues to walk despite the pain. Class lll - Pain forces the patient to stop walking. Class lV - Pain at rest. It is worsened by health conditions such as anemia and heart failure.

questions.question:
Question 4: A 50-year-old male who is a chronic smoker presented to the hospital with intermittent 
claudication pain of both thigh and buttock region on walking about 500 m. Which of the 
following is a likely diagnosis? 1162 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: Arterial disease involving the superficial femoral artery
options.d: Arterial disease involving the profunda femoris artery

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of arterial disease with aortoiliac involvement. Classically, 
the muscle group affected by claudication is one anatomical level below the level of arterial 
disease. Intermittent claudication is a feature of chronic arterial disease or occlusion of the artery. 
Aortoiliac disease affects the infrarenal aorta and iliac arteries. Management involves smoking cessation, lifestyle modifications, and treatment of underlying 
diabetes or hyperlipidemia if present. For claudication, cilostazol or pentoxyfilline is used. Cilostazol is superior to pentoxyfilline. Surgical options include aortoiliac bypass, aortobifemoral bypass, percutaneous transluminal 
angioplasty (PTA), which can be with or without stent placement, and thromboendarterectomy. Correlation of clinical finding

questions.question: Question 5: Critical limb ischemia is characterized by all except
questions.explanation:
Critical limb ischemia is characterized by rest pain and/or ulceration and gangrene. Intermittent 
claudication progresses to rest pain in critical limb ischemia. Rest pain occurs with the limb at rest and is felt in the foot; it is exacerbated by lying down or 
elevation of the foot. Characteristically, the pain is worse at night and it may be lessened by 
hanging the foot out of bed or by sleeping in a chair. The pressure of clothes on the foot usually 
makes the pain worse. Ulceration occurs with severe arterial insufficiency and may present as painful erosion between 
toes or as shallow, non-healing ulcers on the dorsum of the feet, on the shins, and especially 
around the malleoli. The blackened mummified tissues of frank gangrene are unmistakable and 
superadded infection often makes the gangrene wet.

questions.question:
Question 6: In a patient with critical limb ischemia, what is the ankle-brachial pressure index (ABPI) 
likely to be?
questions.explanation: In a patient with critical limb ischemia, the ABPI is < 0.4.

questions.question:
Question 7: A 35-year-old chronic smoker presents with bluish discoloration of the toe along with 
intermittent claudication. Which of the following will be the next appropriate investigation in 
this patient?
questions.explanation:
Chronic smoker presenting with bluish discoloration of the toe along with intermittent 
claudication is suggestive of peripheral arterial disease and duplex scanning will be the next 
appropriate investigation. Duplex Scanning is a major non-invasive technique that uses B-mode ultrasound to provide an 
image of the vessel. Most scanners now have color coding, which allows detailed visualization of 
blood flow in a vessel. Different colors indicate changes in the direction and velocity of flow, with 
areas of high flow usually indicating stenotic lesions. Other options: Option A: CT Angiography (CTA) is more useful in the evaluation of visceral arterial disease (eg. 
mesenteric ischemia). It can be beneficial in peripheral artery diseases where a duplex scan shows 
poor images (aortoiliac segment involvement). CTA is not routinely recommended in peripheral 
artery disease because of concomitant renal dysfunction in these patients which can lead to 
contrast-induced nephropathy. Option B: MR Angiography is time-consuming and expensive, hence not done as the next 
investigation. It is contraindicated in patients with claustrophobia and metallic implants. 1173 
Sold by @itachibot Option C: Digital subtraction angiography (DSA) is an invasive and expensive 
procedure compared to other investigations. The benefits of DSA are that it provides dynamic 
arterial flow information and can be combined with a definitive endovascular intervention when 
indicated. DSA is indicated only when there is a discrepancy in diagnosis or intervention is 
planned. Complications associated with DSA include bleeding, hematoma, false aneurysm 
formation, thrombosis, arterial dissection, distal embolisation, renal dysfunction, and allergic 
reaction.

questions.question:
Question 8: 1163 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following is false regarding the investigation of peripheral arterial disease?

options.a: Duplex scanning is a non invasive technique
options.b: On doppler ultrasound a normal artery has a biphasic signal
options.c: DSA is now the standard technique used
options.d: Computed tomographic angiography is not used routinely to diagnose PAD

questions.explanation:
A normal artery has a triphasic signal. The waveform becomes biphasic in mild-moderate stenosis 
and monophasic in severe stenosis. Option A: Duplex scanning is a major non-invasive technique that uses B-mode 
ultrasound to provide an image of the vessel. Option C: Digital subtraction angiography (DSA) is now the standard technique whereby the 
images obtained are digitized by computer and the extraneous background (bone, soft tissues, 
etc.) is removed to provide clearer images. Option D: Computed tomographic angiography (CTA), and conventional catheter-based 
angiography should not be used for routine diagnostic testing but are performed before potential 
revascularization. These tests define the anatomy that assists in planning for revascularization 
procedures. 1174 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 9: A patient with right leg arterial stenosis is being taken up for angioplasty. Which one of the 
following is incorrect about this procedure?

options.a: It is done for patients with rest pain or tissue necrosis
options.b: It gives best results for management of stenosis below the knee
options.c: Satisfactory dilatation is confirmed by performing angiogram

questions.explanation:
Angioplasty gives the best results for medium-sized vessels hence it is preferred for treating the 
vessels above the knee in peripheral arterial disease. Angioplasty is indicated in patients with rest pain or tissue necrosis. Steps of angioplasty: â€¢ Patients posted for angioplasty are given aspirin (325 mg) and clopidogrel (loading dose of 
300â€“600 mg). â€¢ During the procedure, anticoagulation is achieved by administration of unfractionated heparin, 
enoxaparin, or bivalirudin (a direct thrombin inhibitor). â€¢ The femoral artery is punctured under local anesthetic, followed by insertion of a guidewire. The 
guidewire is negotiated through the stenosis or occlusion under fluoroscopic control. â€¢ A balloon catheter is then inserted over the guidewire and positioned within the lesion. The 
balloon is then inflated at high pressure for approximately 1 minute and deflated. â€¢ Once the angioplasty is done, dilatation is confirmed by performing angiogram. 1175 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 10: Which is the best graft for a femoropopliteal bypass?
questions.explanation:
The great saphenous vein (GSV) is the best as it lasts longer than polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE), 
dacron, and human umbilical vein as a graft in a femoropopliteal bypass. The GSV is the conduit of choice for arterial bypass grafts below the inguinal ligament. For bypass above the inguinal ligament, while both GSV and PTFE grafts have similar patency 
rates in the first 2 years, the GSV is superior thereafter and hence preferred over PTFE or any 
other grafts. The ipsilateral GSV is the conduit of choice for femoropopliteal bypass. When it is not available, 
contralateral GSV should be used. Other veins are preferred when both ipsilateral and 
contralateral GSV is not available and they include a small saphenous vein, cephalic vein, and 
basilic vein. Non-autogenous grafts are used for patients who lack a suitable venous conduit. The most 
commonly used prosthetic conduit is PTFE. Recent studies have shown that heparin-bonded 
PTFE is superior to compared to PTFE without heparin.

questions.question:
Question 11: A 52-year-old man presented with complaints of pain in the right leg right for a day. He has a 
history of recurrent episodes of atrial fibrillation. Which of the following statements are false 
regarding his condition?

options.a: Ischemia beyond 6 hrs is usually irreversible
options.b: Pain, pallor, pulselessness, and parasthesia/anesthesia are characteristic
options.c: Movement of the digits is not affected
options.d: Embolectomy and thrombolysis are treatment options

questions.explanation:
The patient most likely has acute arterial occlusion and atrial fibrillation can predispose to emboli 
formation. In acute arterial occlusion, the movement of the digits will be affected and the limb 
will be cold. Whereas, in venous occlusion, muscle function is not affected. The leg is often affected with: â€¢ Pain â€¢ Pallor 1176 
Sold by @itachibot â€¢ Paralysis â€¢ Loss of pulsation â€¢ Paraesthesia (or anesthesia). Embolic arterial occlusion is an emergency that requires immediate treatment. Ischaemia beyond 
6 hours is usually irreversible and results in limb loss. The diagnosis can be made clinically in a patient who has no history of claudication and has a 
source of emboli, who suddenly develops severe pain or numbness of the limb, which becomes 
cold and mottled.

questions.question:
Question 12: An elderly man is brought to the emergency department with sudden onset severe pain and 
numbness of the left lower limb. He has no previous history of any limb claudication. The 
limb appears to be cold and peripheral pulses are not palpable. What is the most appropriate 
next step?

options.c: CT Angiogram to check for embolus
options.d: Thrombolysis with intra-arterial tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) infusion

questions.explanation:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of sudden arterial occlusion. The immediate next step is 
to administer 5000 IU of heparin to prevent extension of clot. Management of sudden arterial occlusion: â€¢ Embolectomy with Fogartyâ€™s balloon catheter is the definitive treatment of choice. â€¢ Thrombolysis with tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) can be done in cases where there are no 
acute signs of limb ischemia as complete lysis of thrombus in tPA infusion is achieved within 24 
hours, however, it is cautiously used in the elderly due to risk of bleeding diathesis. â€¢ A CT angiogram is performed after the procedure to ensure that the flow to the distal leg has 
been restored. Ischaemia beyond 6 hours is usually irreversible and may result in limb loss. Complications of arterial revascularization â€¢ Compartment syndrome â€¢ Reperfusion syndrome â€¢ Ischaemic neuropathy â€¢ Myoglobinuria â€¢ Renal failure Usually, a prophylactic fasciotomy is done in patients undergoing revascularization surgery to 
prevent compartment syndrome.

questions.question:
Question 13: A 71-year-old man had an acute STEMI for which coronary stenting was performed. On the 
follow-up visit, he reported pain over his toes and discoloration of both feet as shown in the 
image. His creatinine was also elevated. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of atheroembolism. It is also called cholesterol embolism 
or blue toe syndrome. Atheroembolism is a condition in which multiple small deposits of fibrin, platelets, and 
cholesterol debris embolize from proximal atherosclerotic lesions or aneurysmal sites. 1177 
Sold by @itachibot The typical presentation is a patient with ST-elevation myocardial infarction presenting with 
features of limb ischemia (cyanotic discoloration of the toes with pain and tenderness) following 
an intraarterial procedure (angioplasty). Digital vascular occlusion may result in ischemia and the "blue toe" syndrome; digital necrosis and 
gangrene may develop. Localized areas of tenderness, pallor, and livedo reticularis occur at sites 
of emboli. Since the atheroemboli tend to lodge in the small vessels of the limbs and may not 
occlude the large vessels, distal pulses are usually palpable. Large protruding aortic atheromas are a source of emboli that may lead to limb ischemia, as well 
as stroke and renal insufficiency. Skin or muscle biopsy may demonstrate cholesterol crystals. Sharp syndrome, also known as mixed connective tissue disease, is an autoimmune condition with 
features of SLE, systemic sclerosis, and polymyositis. Clinical features include Raynaud's 
syndrome, polyarthritis, myositis, swollen hands, and fingers.

questions.question:
Question 14: 1165 
Sold by @itachibot A patient with untreated severe peripheral arterial disease comes to the surgery OPD with a 
right leg as shown in the image. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

options.a: Usually affects most distal part of a limb
options.b: It is a surgical emergency if crepitus is felt on palpation
options.c: Occurs when tissues are desiccated by gradual slowing of blood stream
options.d: Amputation is not done if severe sepsis is present

questions.explanation:
The patient is suffering from gangrene of the foot. If there is severe sepsis and if re-establishing 
blood supply is difficult(revascularization) then amputation is the preferred choice of treatment. Gangrene refers to death of macroscopic portions of tissue which turn black because of the 
breakdown of haemoglobin and the formation of iron sulphide. It usually affects the most distal part of a limb because of arterial obstruction (from thrombosis, 
embolus or arteritis). Dry gangrene occurs when the tissues are desiccated by gradual slowing of the bloodstream. Wet 
Gangrene occurs when superadded infection and putrefaction are present. Crepitus may be 
palpated as a result of infection by gas-forming organisms commonly in diabetic foot problems.

questions.question:
Question 15: A 51-year-old, diabetic patient presents with the following features during a village health 
camp. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition? 1166 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: Due to immunosuppression caused by elevated glucose levels
options.b: Repeated injury leads to Charcot's foot
options.c: Glycemic control and antibiotic therapy is first line managment
options.d: Sensory nerves are affected in the late stage of disease

questions.explanation:
The image and clinical scenario are suggestive of diabetic gangrene of the foot. It is accompanied 
by sensory loss in the early stage of the disease and motor involvement in the late stage. Diabetic gangrene is caused by a combination of three factors: â€¢ Ischemia secondary to macrovascular disease and microvascular dysfunction, â€¢ Peripheral sensorimotor neuropathy, which leads to trophic skin changes â€¢ Immunosuppression is caused by excess sugar in the tissues, which predisposes to infection Diabetic gangrene is accompanied by loss of sensation and reflexes which lead to repeated injury. 
There occurs an imbalance between the flexors and extensors of the foot which causes deformities 
known as Charcot's foot (neuropathic joints). Initial treatment comprises strict glycemic control and antibiotic therapy. The gangrene is treated 
by drainage of pus, debridement of dead tissue with local amputation of necrotic digits. 1178 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 16: A 40-year-old man presents to the casualty with complaints of recurrent episodes of syncope 
and cramping of his left arm. Symptoms mostly occur during his evening badminton practice 
sessions. Which of the following is incorrect about this condition?

options.a: Due to occlusion in the 3rd part of subclavian artery
options.b: Distal pulse of the affected side is feeble
options.c: CT angiography is used to visualize retrograde blood flow

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of subclavian steal syndrome. In subclavian steal 
syndrome, the first part of the subclavian artery is occluded. Subclavian steal syndrome is characterized by the presence of stenosis in the first part of the 
subclavian artery either due to atherosclerotic changes or emboli. It leads to reversed flow in the 
vertebral artery causing cerebral ischemia. Symptoms include dizziness, syncope on arm exercise. Occasionally, distal pulses in the arm of 
the affected side are found to be feeble. Investigations include duplex ultrasonography, CT, and MR angiography. It can be treated by angioplasty, stenting or by extra-thoracic subclavian bypass.

questions.question: Question 17: In Paget-Schroetter syndrome which of the following structure is affected?
questions.explanation:
In Paget-Schroetter syndrome, the subclavian vein is affected. Compression of subclavian vein between anterior scalene, clavicle, and the first rib can produce 
axillary-subclavian vein thrombosis. It results in severe upper extremity pain and swelling, that 
is exaggerated by exercise. Activities such as throwing, swimming, and weightlifting can cause microtrauma of the venous 
intima that initiates thrombus formation.

questions.question:
Question 18: A 26-year-old male patient who came to the OPD with complaints of pain and numbness of 
the arm is diagnosed with thoracic outlet syndrome. Which nerve is involved in this 
condition?
questions.explanation:
In thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS) the lower two nerve roots of the brachial plexus, C8 and T1 are 
most commonly involved and produce pain and paresthesia along the ulnar nerve distribution. 1179 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 19: A resident is trying to elicit symptoms of thoracic outlet syndrome in a patient. He asks the 
patient to keep both arms in the 90Â° abduction-external rotation position and to open and 
close the hands slowly over a 3-minute period. What is this test called?
questions.explanation:
The test described in the question is a provocative test for thoracic outlet syndrome called Roos 
test (extended arm stress test).

questions.question:
Question 20: A young woman presents to the hospital with sudden discoloration of the hands. Which of the 
following would suggest a diagnosis of acrocyanosis over Raynaudâ€™s phenomenon?
questions.explanation:
In acrocyanosis, there is no pain or numbness. In Raynaudâ€™s phenomenon, there is pain and 
tingling sensation. Acrocyanosis is a chronic, benign vasoconstrictive disorder. It is due to arterial vasoconstriction 
and secondary dilation of the capillaries and venules that results in persistent cyanosis of the 
hands and feet. It can be primary or secondary. Primary acrocyanosis is more common in females with an onset <30 years. Trophic skin 
changes and ulcerations do not occur and examination reveals normal pulses. The disorder can be distinguished from Raynaudâ€™s phenomenon: â€¢ Because it is persistent and not episodic â€¢ There is no pain in acrocyanosis whereas in Raynaud's phenomenon there is pain and numbness â€¢ The discoloration extends proximally from the digits â€¢ Blanching does not occur

questions.question:
Question 21: A 24-year-old female nurse was on her way to the hospital for her early morning shift. 
Suddenly she started to notice pain in her fingers which were turning pale and numb after 
which they turned blue. Which of the following statements are false regarding this condition?

options.a: Triggered by cold as well as stress
options.b: Calcium channel blockers are used for treatment
options.c: Mainstay of treatment includes avoidance of triggers
options.d: Is not associated with autoimmune diseases

questions.explanation:

Raynaud's phenomenon are seen in association with autoimmune diseases such as scleroderma, 
systemic lupus erythematosus etc. Raynaudâ€™s phenomenon is characterized by triphasic color response of the fingers or toes: â€¢ Digital blanching or pallor â€¢ Cyanosis â€¢ Rubor 1180

questions.question: Question 22: Which of the following is an incorrect statement about Buerger's disease?
questions.explanation:
Statements 1 and 3 are false. In thromboangitis obliterans, there is normal brachial and popliteal 
pulses but reduced or absent radial, ulnar, and/or tibial pulses. It is most common in male 
smokers, usually under the age of 30 years. Thromboangiitis obliterans (Buergerâ€™s disease) is an inflammatory occlusive vascular disorder 
involving small and medium-sized arteries and veins in the distal upper and lower extremities. The clinical features include a triad of: â€¢ Claudication of the affected extremity â€¢ Raynaudâ€™s phenomenon â€¢ Migratory superficial vein thrombophlebitis Patients frequently have rest pain, ulceration, and digital gangrene. 1181 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 23: A 34-year-old male construction worker presents with exertional pain and darkening of the 
skin in both forearms and hands as shown in the image. He smokes 1 pack of cigarettes per 
day and has no comorbidities On examination, brachial pulses are palpable but radial and 
ulnar pulses are feeble. Angiography of his upper extremity shows smooth tapering segmental 
lesions in the distal arterial vessels. Which of the following treatments has the greatest chance 
of success?
questions.explanation:
The clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of thromboangiitis obliterans. There is no specific 
treatment except abstinence from tobacco. Key findings in this patient is age < 40 years, 
smoker, and involvement of upper extremity. Although the cause of thromboangiitis obliterans is not known, there is a definite relationship to 
cigarette smoking in patients with this disorder. There is no specific treatment except abstention 
from tobacco. MRA, CTA, and conventional arteriography show smooth, tapering segmental lesions in the distal 
vessels with collateral vessels at sites of vascular occlusion. The prognosis is poor in individuals who continue to smoke. Surgical revascularization is not possible due to extensive vascular inflammation and damage. 
Anticoagulants and glucocorticoids are not helpful. If the condition worsens, amputation may be 
required.

questions.question:
Question 24: A 50-year-old chronic smoker presented with cramping pain in the buttocks and erectile 
dysfunction for the past 6 months. He has no history of bladder dysfunction or fecal 
incontinence. Examination revealed absent femoral pulses and normal sensory and motor 
system. How will you surgically manage this patient?
questions.explanation:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of Leriche syndrome. The treatment of choice here is 
aortobifemoral grafting. Leriche syndrome is due to occlusion at the aortic bifurcation and is characterized by â€¢ Buttock claudication â€¢ Impotence â€¢ Absence of femoral pulse. â€¢ No sensory or motor deficit â€¢ Normal reflexes Atherosclerosis is the most common cause of Leriche syndrome. Differential diagnosis includes â€¢ Abdominal dissection â€¢ Spinal canal stenosis â€¢ Spinal disc herniation Aortofemoral grafting is done in unilateral iliac vessel occlusion. Iliofemoral grafting is done for unilateral occlusion of distal common iliac or external iliac artery. Illiopopliteal grafting is done for femoral artery occlusion. 1182

questions.question: Question 25: Which of the following is not an indication for a carotid endarterectomy?

options.c: Systolic pressure is maintained at <100 mm of Hg in aortic aneurysm rupture
options.d: USG is used to diagnose abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture

questions.explanation:
Dysphonia is not an indication for carotid endarterectomy. Carotid endarterectomy is done in 
carotid artery stenosis. Indications of carotid endarterectomy in symptomatic patients. CT angiography showing 70% or more stenosis and â€¢ Ipsilateral amaurosis fugax or monocular blindness â€¢ Contralateral facial paralysis or paresthesia â€¢ Arm/leg paralysis or paresthesia â€¢ Hemianopia â€¢ Dysphasia 1183
